html:
• anchor

    Rendering of Arts of Africa galleries, The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Image by WHY Architecture

    The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s soon-to-be completed transformation of its Michael C Rockefeller Wing, designed by Kulapat Yantrasast of WHY Architecture in collaboration with Beyer, Blinder, Belle, has been revealed following a four-year and $70 million project that will open to the public on May 31st, 2025.

    Yantrasast said it affirms his practice’s belief that "museums are true sites of empathy." The project began construction in 2021 and encompassed over 40,000 square feet, adding a series of reimagined galleries for the Met’s Arts of Africa, Ancient Americas, and Oceania collections that engender a "welcoming and memorable sense of place" through which visitors can experience art from five continents and hundreds of different cultures.

    WHY has been working closely with the museum’s Design Department to create a more congruous dialogue with the existing architecture of the space that is both more respectful of the vernacular traditions of each region and knowledgeable of a "revolution in our understanding" of the individual achievements of their peoples. 

    From the beginning, the goal for the transformation was to upgrade the museum's capacity for digital technology in order to augment the curatorial experience and provide a better understanding of each object that is now protected by a sloping glass wall on the wing’s park-facing south facade. 

    The Met says they have accomplished this while introducing what Curator in Charge Alisa LaGamma called a "wealth of contextual detail." This is the largest reinstallation of its collections since the Rockefeller Wing first opened in 1982.

    Stone platforms located in the Arts of the Ancient Americas galleries echo the layout of landmarks from Mesoamerica and the Andes, while in the Arts of Africa section, architectural details of the Great Mosque of Jenne in Mali are referenced by a succession of horizontal baffles. 

    Several new commissions for the Arts of Oceania galleries made by Indigenous artists highlight a further reemphasis on gender roles and other social factors. A new gallery dedicated to preserving light-sensitive ancient Andean textiles will be premiered as the first of its kind in the United States as well. 

    Support for this new "community-based approach" to displaying non-Western art is included as one of The Met's six projects included in its $2 billion capital improvements plan. The New York Times spoke to the Vice President of Capital Projects, Jhaelen Hernandez-Eli, about sustainable approaches taken in the renovation in November of 2023. Another, Frida Escobedo's redesign and expansion of the adjacent Tang Wing for Modern and Contemporary Art, is expected to begin construction next year.
